content: Mix water, corn syrup, sugar, and salt in a saucepan. Pour 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of water into the saucepan first, then add 2.75 fluid ounces (81 mL) of light corn syrup, 5 ounces (140 g) of sugar, and 1 gram (0.035 oz) of salt. Use a whisk to stir all these ingredients together. [1] After you've whisked the ingredients together, you should be left with a smooth, syrupy mixture. Use a stainless-steel saucepan, if possible, since a nonstick saucepan will have a Teflon coating that may come off as you stir the syrup and end up in your whipped cream. If you can’t use a stainless-steel saucepan, definitely avoid using a metal whisk to stir the water, corn syrup, and sugar. Set the saucepan over medium heat and cook the syrup for 3 minutes. Turn the temperature dial on your stove to 5 (if it’s out of 10) to set it to medium. Use a fork to stir the syrupy mixture and cook it on the stovetop until it starts bubbling around the edges, or around 3 minutes. [2] If your stovetop temperature dial doesn’t go up to 10, simply turn the dial to the middle number to set it to medium. For example, if your dial goes up to 12, turn the dial to 6 for medium heat. If your saucepan is a nonstick pan instead of stainless steel, don’t use a metallic fork to stir the syrup, as this might scrape off pieces of Teflon. Use a small wooden spoon or other non-metallic stirrer instead to avoid getting Teflon in your syrup. Increase the heat to medium-high and cook the syrup to 250 °F (121 °C). Set the temperature dial to 6 or 7 out of 10 to set your stove to medium-high heat and continue cooking the syrup. Use a thermometer to monitor the syrup’s temperature until it reaches 250 °F (121 °C). [3] If the numbers on your temperature dial don’t go from 1 to 10, medium-high heat will be the number that is slightly less than halfway between the middle number and the highest number. For example, if your temperature dial went up to 8, then medium-high would be between 5 and 6. You don’t need to stir the syrup during this step, just allow it to cook. It should take about 4 minutes for your syrup to reach 250 °F (121 °C). Transfer the syrup to a heat-safe bowl and let it cool to 212 °F (100 °C). Once the syrup has reached 250 °F (121 °C), take the saucepan off of the stove and carefully pour the syrup into a heat-resistant or heat-safe bowl. Allow the syrup to cool until it reaches 212 °F (100 °C), or about 3 minutes. [4] Most bowls made out of ceramic or glass are generally heat-resistant. To be safe, check the bottom of your bowl or the packaging it came in for a “heat-safe,” “oven-safe,” or “microwave-safe” label to make sure it’s safe to use with hot syrup. Mix the gelatin and 1 fluid ounce (30 mL) of cold water in a small bowl. Put the water in the bowl first, then sprinkle the gelatin on top of it. Use a fork to stir the ingredients together until the gelatin is completely dissolved. [5] Be sure to use unflavored gelatin; mixing a flavored gelatin powder with the water might change the way your Cool Whip tastes once it’s done. Add your gelatin mix to the syrup and whisk them into a larger mixture. Take the mixture you made from the powdered gelatin and water and pour it into the syrup. Use a hand mixer to whisk the mix and the syrup together for 5-7 minutes until the mixture becomes 3 times larger in volume. [6] Set your hand mixer to medium-high speed when you mix the gelatin and syrup together. The new mixture should be cool and a snowy white color by the time you’re done whisking. Whisk together the milk, powdered milk, and vanilla extract in a separate bowl. Pour 0.25 cups (59 mL) of cold milk, 12.75 grams (0.450 oz) of powdered milk, and 2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) of vanilla extract into a second bowl, then use a whisk or a hand mixer on low speed to beat the ingredients together. Whisk the ingredients until they’re completely mixed together into a smooth mixture. [7] Make sure the powdered milk is completely dissolved into the mixture and that there are no clumps before proceeding to the next step. Mix your vanilla milk mixture into the syrup. Pour 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of the vanilla milk mixture into your gelatin and syrup mix at a time and beat it with your hand mixer until the milk is completely incorporated into the syrup. Repeat this process until you’ve added all of your vanilla milk mixture to the syrup. [8] Continue using your hand mixer at a medium-high speed throughout the process of adding the vanilla milk to the mixture. Your new mixture should be completely smooth by the time you’ve finished incorporating the vanilla milk into it. Cover the mixture with saran wrap and let it sit for 2-3 hours. Make sure the mixture is tightly covered with saran wrap so that air doesn’t get it into the container and cause the mix to go bad. Don’t put the mixture in the refrigerator at this point; it needs to sit out at room temperature for at least 2 hours to ensure your cool whip has a stable structure once it’s finished. [9] Don’t leave the mixture out at room temperature for longer than 8 hours; this will cause the dairy products in the mix to spoil. Drizzle heavy cream into the mixture while mixing it at a low speed. Pour 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of heavy cream into the mixture at a time and use your hand mixer to whisk the mixture at a low speed until the cream has been completely mixed into it. Repeat this process until all of the heavy cream has been added to the mixture. [10] Beat the mixture at medium speed until it begins to form peaks. The peaks should be floppy but relatively firm. Once your whipped cream is able to hold medium-sized peaks that don’t disappear immediately when you stop mixing, it’s ready to be used. [11] Use your whipped cream immediately or refrigerate or freeze it. For the freshest taste, use your homemade Cool Whip as soon as you’ve finished making it. However, if you don’t want to use the cream right away, transfer it into an airtight container and store it in the refrigerator or freezer to keep it from going bad. [12] Whipped cream will stay fresh in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks or in the freezer for up to 3 months.

<p>Cool Whip is a very popular whipped cream that’s usually used as a topping for desserts or fruit. If you love to eat Cool Whip, or have never had it but want to try it, you’ll be happy to hear how easy it is to make from scratch! By mixing together powdered gelatin, milk, heavy cream, and other common ingredients you probably already have in your kitchen, you can make whipped cream in just a few hours.</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Ingredients">Ingredients</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="ingredients">
<ul>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_98277c72eb3b5288872b21972e168978" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_98277c72eb3b5288872b21972e168978" name="item_98277c72eb3b5288872b21972e168978_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">5 grams (0.18 oz) unflavored powdered gelatin</div>
</li>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_0bd46b39c73eabf26c41ff9f5a4e5005" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_0bd46b39c73eabf26c41ff9f5a4e5005" name="item_0bd46b39c73eabf26c41ff9f5a4e5005_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">3 fluid ounces (89 mL) cold water</div>
</li>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_8a17d824b2c1183136d118fa55639ff3" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_8a17d824b2c1183136d118fa55639ff3" name="item_8a17d824b2c1183136d118fa55639ff3_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">0.25 cups (59 mL) cold milk</div>
</li>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_0fa1d554e025c822c16da2180c72b8b8" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_0fa1d554e025c822c16da2180c72b8b8" name="item_0fa1d554e025c822c16da2180c72b8b8_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) vanilla extract</div>
</li>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_d32b65f8daaebd6720b6f34bc3625455" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_d32b65f8daaebd6720b6f34bc3625455" name="item_d32b65f8daaebd6720b6f34bc3625455_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">2.75 fluid ounces (81 mL) light corn syrup</div>
</li>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_fcd1c0a7ee5efa32effe5390aef5c871" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_fcd1c0a7ee5efa32effe5390aef5c871" name="item_fcd1c0a7ee5efa32effe5390aef5c871_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">5 ounces (140 g) sugar</div>
</li>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_64dc3d3b96f90ec1de0b87137476d132" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_64dc3d3b96f90ec1de0b87137476d132" name="item_64dc3d3b96f90ec1de0b87137476d132_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">1 gram (0.035 oz) salt</div>
</li>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_a3cb20c32a286785cf18df6f0e8d3359" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_a3cb20c32a286785cf18df6f0e8d3359" name="item_a3cb20c32a286785cf18df6f0e8d3359_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">14 fluid ounces (410 mL) heavy cream</div>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Cooking_Your_Syrup_Base_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Cooking_Your_Syrup_Base">Cooking Your Syrup Base</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/3/30/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-1-Version-3.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/1/1d/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-1-Version-3.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-1-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/1/14/Make Cool Whip Step 1 Version 3.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-a333cd480c" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip">
<img class="m-video-wm-img" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/><script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script>
</div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Mix water, corn syrup, sugar, and salt in a saucepan.</b> Pour 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of water into the saucepan first, then add 2.75 fluid ounces (81 mL) of light corn syrup, 5 ounces (140 g) of sugar, and 1 gram (0.035 oz) of salt. Use a whisk to stir all these ingredients together.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-a333cd480c'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>After you've whisked the ingredients together, you should be left with a smooth, syrupy mixture.</li>
<li>Use a stainless-steel saucepan, if possible, since a nonstick saucepan will have a Teflon coating that may come off as you stir the syrup and end up in your whipped cream. If you can’t use a stainless-steel saucepan, definitely avoid using a metal whisk to stir the water, corn syrup, and sugar.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/c9/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-2-Version-3.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/8/80/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-2-Version-3.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-2-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-2-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/7/7a/Make Cool Whip Step 2 Version 3.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-dd1882dc36" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Set the saucepan over medium heat and cook the syrup for 3 minutes.</b> Turn the temperature dial on your stove to 5 (if it’s out of 10) to set it to medium. Use a fork to stir the syrupy mixture and cook it on the stovetop until it starts bubbling around the edges, or around 3 minutes.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-dd1882dc36'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>If your stovetop temperature dial doesn’t go up to 10, simply turn the dial to the middle number to set it to medium. For example, if your dial goes up to 12, turn the dial to 6 for medium heat.</li>
<li>If your saucepan is a nonstick pan instead of stainless steel, don’t use a metallic fork to stir the syrup, as this might scrape off pieces of Teflon. Use a small wooden spoon or other non-metallic stirrer instead to avoid getting Teflon in your syrup.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/8/82/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-3-Version-3.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/c0/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-3-Version-3.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-3-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-3-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/c/c2/Make Cool Whip Step 3 Version 3.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-61091f9084" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Increase the heat to medium-high and cook the syrup to 250 °F (121 °C).</b> Set the temperature dial to 6 or 7 out of 10 to set your stove to medium-high heat and continue cooking the syrup. Use a thermometer to monitor the syrup’s temperature until it reaches 250 °F (121 °C).<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-61091f9084'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>If the numbers on your temperature dial don’t go from 1 to 10, medium-high heat will be the number that is slightly less than halfway between the middle number and the highest number. For example, if your temperature dial went up to 8, then medium-high would be between 5 and 6.</li>
<li>You don’t need to stir the syrup during this step, just allow it to cook.</li>
<li>It should take about 4 minutes for your syrup to reach 250 °F (121 °C).</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/cb/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-4-Version-3.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/c5/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-4-Version-3.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-4-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-4-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/b/b0/Make Cool Whip Step 4 Version 3.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-6136f9a161" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Transfer the syrup to a heat-safe bowl and let it cool to 212 °F (100 °C).</b> Once the syrup has reached 250 °F (121 °C), take the saucepan off of the stove and carefully pour the syrup into a heat-resistant or heat-safe bowl. Allow the syrup to cool until it reaches 212 °F (100 °C), or about 3 minutes.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-6136f9a161'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>Most bowls made out of ceramic or glass are generally heat-resistant. To be safe, check the bottom of your bowl or the packaging it came in for a “heat-safe,” “oven-safe,” or “microwave-safe” label to make sure it’s safe to use with hot syrup.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Combining_Your_Syrup.2C_Gelatin.2C_and_Milk_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Combining_Your_Syrup.2C_Gelatin.2C_and_Milk">Combining Your Syrup, Gelatin, and Milk</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/6/61/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-5-Version-3.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/2/2d/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-5-Version-3.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f8/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-5-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-5-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/3/31/Make Cool Whip Step 5 Version 3.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-9f604ec9bb" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Mix the gelatin and 1 fluid ounce (30 mL) of cold water in a small bowl.</b> Put the water in the bowl first, then sprinkle the gelatin on top of it. Use a fork to stir the ingredients together until the gelatin is completely dissolved.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-9f604ec9bb'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>Be sure to use unflavored gelatin; mixing a flavored gelatin powder with the water might change the way your Cool Whip tastes once it’s done.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/8/8c/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-6-Version-3.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d4/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-6-Version-3.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-6-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-6-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/a/ae/Make Cool Whip Step 6 Version 3.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-e226d00cea" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add your gelatin mix to the syrup and whisk them into a larger mixture.</b> Take the mixture you made from the powdered gelatin and water and pour it into the syrup. Use a hand mixer to whisk the mix and the syrup together for 5-7 minutes until the mixture becomes 3 times larger in volume.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-e226d00cea'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>Set your hand mixer to medium-high speed when you mix the gelatin and syrup together.</li>
<li>The new mixture should be cool and a snowy white color by the time you’re done whisking.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/99/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-7-Version-3.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/ad/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-7-Version-3.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-7-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-7-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/4/48/Make Cool Whip Step 7 Version 3.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-255118199c" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Whisk together the milk, powdered milk, and vanilla extract in a separate bowl.</b> Pour 0.25 cups (59 mL) of cold milk, 12.75 grams (0.450 oz) of powdered milk, and 2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) of vanilla extract into a second bowl, then use a whisk or a hand mixer on low speed to beat the ingredients together. Whisk the ingredients until they’re completely mixed together into a smooth mixture.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-255118199c'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>Make sure the powdered milk is completely dissolved into the mixture and that there are no clumps before proceeding to the next step.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/4e/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-8-Version-3.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/90/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-8-Version-3.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-8-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-8-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/8/89/Make Cool Whip Step 8 Version 3.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-191ff90863" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Mix your vanilla milk mixture into the syrup.</b> Pour 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of the vanilla milk mixture into your gelatin and syrup mix at a time and beat it with your hand mixer until the milk is completely incorporated into the syrup. Repeat this process until you’ve added all of your vanilla milk mixture to the syrup.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-191ff90863'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>Continue using your hand mixer at a medium-high speed throughout the process of adding the vanilla milk to the mixture.</li>
<li>Your new mixture should be completely smooth by the time you’ve finished incorporating the vanilla milk into it.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/bf/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-9-Version-3.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/f/f0/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-9-Version-3.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-9-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-9-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/f/fe/Make Cool Whip Step 9 Version 3.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-30759aeedc" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Cover the mixture with saran wrap and let it sit for 2-3 hours.</b> Make sure the mixture is tightly covered with saran wrap so that air doesn’t get it into the container and cause the mix to go bad. Don’t put the mixture in the refrigerator at this point; it needs to sit out at room temperature for at least 2 hours to ensure your cool whip has a stable structure once it’s finished.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-30759aeedc'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>Don’t leave the mixture out at room temperature for longer than 8 hours; this will cause the dairy products in the mix to spoil.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Finishing_and_Storing_Your_Whipped_Cream_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Finishing_and_Storing_Your_Whipped_Cream">Finishing and Storing Your Whipped Cream</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/97/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-10-Version-2.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/c8/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-10-Version-2.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" data-src="/9/9e/Make Cool Whip Step 10 Version 2.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-a415b39519" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Drizzle heavy cream into the mixture while mixing it at a low speed.</b> Pour 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of heavy cream into the mixture at a time and use your hand mixer to whisk the mixture at a low speed until the cream has been completely mixed into it. Repeat this process until all of the heavy cream has been added to the mixture.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-a415b39519'));
//]]>
</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/1/1f/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-11-Version-2.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/70/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-11-Version-2.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" data-src="/b/b5/Make Cool Whip Step 11 Version 2.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-34f26f58b6" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Beat the mixture at medium speed until it begins to form peaks.</b> The peaks should be floppy but relatively firm. Once your whipped cream is able to hold medium-sized peaks that don’t disappear immediately when you stop mixing, it’s ready to be used.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-34f26f58b6'));
//]]>
</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/dd/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-12-Version-2.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/40/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-12-Version-2.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Make-Cool-Whip-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Make-Cool-Whip-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" data-src="/a/ad/Make Cool Whip Step 12 Version 2.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-cb88cd4630" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Make Cool Whip"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use your whipped cream immediately or refrigerate or freeze it.</b> For the freshest taste, use your homemade Cool Whip as soon as you’ve finished making it. However, if you don’t want to use the cream right away, transfer it into an airtight container and store it in the refrigerator or freezer to keep it from going bad.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-cb88cd4630'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>Whipped cream will stay fresh in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks or in the freezer for up to 3 months.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To make Cool Whip, start by mixing water, corn syrup, sugar, and salt in a saucepan and heating the mixture over medium heat. After 3 minutes, turn the heat up to medium-high and cook the mixture for 4 minutes. Then, transfer the mixture to a bowl and let it cool for 3 minutes. While that's cooling, mix gelatin and cold water in a separate bowl, and then whisk it into the corn syrup mixture for several minutes. Finally, add milk, powdered milk, and vanilla to the mixture and let it sit for 2-3 hours. <span id="summary_last_sentence">To learn how to store and use homemade Cool Whip, scroll down!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

        "width": 1200,
        "height": 675
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",

    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Cooking Your Syrup Base",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Mix water, corn syrup, sugar, and salt in a saucepan. Pour 2 fluid ounces (59\u00a0mL) of water into the saucepan first, then add 2.75 fluid ounces (81\u00a0mL) of light corn syrup, 5 ounces (140\u00a0g) of sugar, and 1 gram (0.035\u00a0oz) of salt. Use a whisk to stir all these ingredients together.[1]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-a333cd480c'));\n\/\/]]>\n\nAfter you've whisked the ingredients together, you should be left with a smooth, syrupy mixture.\nUse a stainless-steel saucepan, if possible, since a nonstick saucepan will have a Teflon coating that may come off as you stir the syrup and end up in your whipped cream. If you can\u2019t use a stainless-steel saucepan, definitely avoid using a metal whisk to stir the water, corn syrup, and sugar."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Set the saucepan over medium heat and cook the syrup for 3 minutes. Turn the temperature dial on your stove to 5 (if it\u2019s out of 10) to set it to medium. Use a fork to stir the syrupy mixture and cook it on the stovetop until it starts bubbling around the edges, or around 3 minutes.[2]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-dd1882dc36'));\n\/\/]]>\n\nIf your stovetop temperature dial doesn\u2019t go up to 10, simply turn the dial to the middle number to set it to medium. For example, if your dial goes up to 12, turn the dial to 6 for medium heat.\nIf your saucepan is a nonstick pan instead of stainless steel, don\u2019t use a metallic fork to stir the syrup, as this might scrape off pieces of Teflon. Use a small wooden spoon or other non-metallic stirrer instead to avoid getting Teflon in your syrup."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Increase the heat to medium-high and cook the syrup to 250\u00a0\u00b0F (121\u00a0\u00b0C). Set the temperature dial to 6 or 7 out of 10 to set your stove to medium-high heat and continue cooking the syrup. Use a thermometer to monitor the syrup\u2019s temperature until it reaches 250\u00a0\u00b0F (121\u00a0\u00b0C).[3]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-61091f9084'));\n\/\/]]>\n\nIf the numbers on your temperature dial don\u2019t go from 1 to 10, medium-high heat will be the number that is slightly less than halfway between the middle number and the highest number. For example, if your temperature dial went up to 8, then medium-high would be between 5 and 6.\nYou don\u2019t need to stir the syrup during this step, just allow it to cook.\nIt should take about 4 minutes for your syrup to reach 250\u00a0\u00b0F (121\u00a0\u00b0C)."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Transfer the syrup to a heat-safe bowl and let it cool to 212\u00a0\u00b0F (100\u00a0\u00b0C). Once the syrup has reached 250\u00a0\u00b0F (121\u00a0\u00b0C), take the saucepan off of the stove and carefully pour the syrup into a heat-resistant or heat-safe bowl. Allow the syrup to cool until it reaches 212\u00a0\u00b0F (100\u00a0\u00b0C), or about 3 minutes.[4]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-6136f9a161'));\n\/\/]]>\n\nMost bowls made out of ceramic or glass are generally heat-resistant. To be safe, check the bottom of your bowl or the packaging it came in for a \u201cheat-safe,\u201d \u201coven-safe,\u201d or \u201cmicrowave-safe\u201d label to make sure it\u2019s safe to use with hot syrup."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Combining Your Syrup, Gelatin, and Milk",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Mix the gelatin and 1 fluid ounce (30\u00a0mL) of cold water in a small bowl. Put the water in the bowl first, then sprinkle the gelatin on top of it. Use a fork to stir the ingredients together until the gelatin is completely dissolved.[5]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-9f604ec9bb'));\n\/\/]]>\n\nBe sure to use unflavored gelatin; mixing a flavored gelatin powder with the water might change the way your Cool Whip tastes once it\u2019s done."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Add your gelatin mix to the syrup and whisk them into a larger mixture. Take the mixture you made from the powdered gelatin and water and pour it into the syrup. Use a hand mixer to whisk the mix and the syrup together for 5-7 minutes until the mixture becomes 3 times larger in volume.[6]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-e226d00cea'));\n\/\/]]>\n\nSet your hand mixer to medium-high speed when you mix the gelatin and syrup together.\nThe new mixture should be cool and a snowy white color by the time you\u2019re done whisking."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Whisk together the milk, powdered milk, and vanilla extract in a separate bowl. Pour 0.25 cups (59\u00a0mL) of cold milk, 12.75 grams (0.450\u00a0oz) of powdered milk, and 2 teaspoons (9.9\u00a0mL) of vanilla extract into a second bowl, then use a whisk or a hand mixer on low speed to beat the ingredients together. Whisk the ingredients until they\u2019re completely mixed together into a smooth mixture.[7]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-255118199c'));\n\/\/]]>\n\nMake sure the powdered milk is completely dissolved into the mixture and that there are no clumps before proceeding to the next step."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Mix your vanilla milk mixture into the syrup. Pour 2 tablespoons (30\u00a0mL) of the vanilla milk mixture into your gelatin and syrup mix at a time and beat it with your hand mixer until the milk is completely incorporated into the syrup. Repeat this process until you\u2019ve added all of your vanilla milk mixture to the syrup.[8]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-191ff90863'));\n\/\/]]>\n\nContinue using your hand mixer at a medium-high speed throughout the process of adding the vanilla milk to the mixture.\nYour new mixture should be completely smooth by the time you\u2019ve finished incorporating the vanilla milk into it."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Cover the mixture with saran wrap and let it sit for 2-3 hours. Make sure the mixture is tightly covered with saran wrap so that air doesn\u2019t get it into the container and cause the mix to go bad. Don\u2019t put the mixture in the refrigerator at this point; it needs to sit out at room temperature for at least 2 hours to ensure your cool whip has a stable structure once it\u2019s finished.[9]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-30759aeedc'));\n\/\/]]>\n\nDon\u2019t leave the mixture out at room temperature for longer than 8 hours; this will cause the dairy products in the mix to spoil."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Finishing and Storing Your Whipped Cream",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Drizzle heavy cream into the mixture while mixing it at a low speed. Pour 2 fluid ounces (59\u00a0mL) of heavy cream into the mixture at a time and use your hand mixer to whisk the mixture at a low speed until the cream has been completely mixed into it. Repeat this process until all of the heavy cream has been added to the mixture.[10]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-a415b39519'));\n\/\/]]>"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Beat the mixture at medium speed until it begins to form peaks. The peaks should be floppy but relatively firm. Once your whipped cream is able to hold medium-sized peaks that don\u2019t disappear immediately when you stop mixing, it\u2019s ready to be used.[11]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-34f26f58b6'));\n\/\/]]>"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use your whipped cream immediately or refrigerate or freeze it. For the freshest taste, use your homemade Cool Whip as soon as you\u2019ve finished making it. However, if you don\u2019t want to use the cream right away, transfer it into an airtight container and store it in the refrigerator or freezer to keep it from going bad.[12]\n\/\/<![CDATA[\nif (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-cb88cd4630'));\n\/\/]]>\n\nWhipped cream will stay fresh in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks or in the freezer for up to 3 months."
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],
    "description": "How to Make Cool Whip. Cool Whip is a very popular whipped cream that's usually used as a topping for desserts or fruit. If you love to eat Cool Whip, or have never had it but want to try it, you'll be happy to hear how easy it is to make..."

title: How to Make Cool Whip
content_html:
Mix water, corn syrup, sugar, and salt in a saucepan. Pour 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of water into the saucepan first, then add 2.75 fluid ounces (81 mL) of light corn syrup, 5 ounces (140 g) of sugar, and 1 gram (0.035 oz) of salt. Use a whisk to stir all these ingredients together.[1]
  • After you've whisked the ingredients together, you should be left with a smooth, syrupy mixture.
  • Use a stainless-steel saucepan, if possible, since a nonstick saucepan will have a Teflon coating that may come off as you stir the syrup and end up in your whipped cream. If you can’t use a stainless-steel saucepan, definitely avoid using a metal whisk to stir the water, corn syrup, and sugar.
Set the saucepan over medium heat and cook the syrup for 3 minutes. Turn the temperature dial on your stove to 5 (if it’s out of 10) to set it to medium. Use a fork to stir the syrupy mixture and cook it on the stovetop until it starts bubbling around the edges, or around 3 minutes.[2]
  • If your stovetop temperature dial doesn’t go up to 10, simply turn the dial to the middle number to set it to medium. For example, if your dial goes up to 12, turn the dial to 6 for medium heat.
  • If your saucepan is a nonstick pan instead of stainless steel, don’t use a metallic fork to stir the syrup, as this might scrape off pieces of Teflon. Use a small wooden spoon or other non-metallic stirrer instead to avoid getting Teflon in your syrup.
Increase the heat to medium-high and cook the syrup to 250 °F (121 °C). Set the temperature dial to 6 or 7 out of 10 to set your stove to medium-high heat and continue cooking the syrup. Use a thermometer to monitor the syrup’s temperature until it reaches 250 °F (121 °C).[3]
  • If the numbers on your temperature dial don’t go from 1 to 10, medium-high heat will be the number that is slightly less than halfway between the middle number and the highest number. For example, if your temperature dial went up to 8, then medium-high would be between 5 and 6.
  • You don’t need to stir the syrup during this step, just allow it to cook.
  • It should take about 4 minutes for your syrup to reach 250 °F (121 °C).
Transfer the syrup to a heat-safe bowl and let it cool to 212 °F (100 °C). Once the syrup has reached 250 °F (121 °C), take the saucepan off of the stove and carefully pour the syrup into a heat-resistant or heat-safe bowl. Allow the syrup to cool until it reaches 212 °F (100 °C), or about 3 minutes.[4]
  • Most bowls made out of ceramic or glass are generally heat-resistant. To be safe, check the bottom of your bowl or the packaging it came in for a “heat-safe,” “oven-safe,” or “microwave-safe” label to make sure it’s safe to use with hot syrup.
Mix the gelatin and 1 fluid ounce (30 mL) of cold water in a small bowl. Put the water in the bowl first, then sprinkle the gelatin on top of it. Use a fork to stir the ingredients together until the gelatin is completely dissolved.[5]
  • Be sure to use unflavored gelatin; mixing a flavored gelatin powder with the water might change the way your Cool Whip tastes once it’s done.
Add your gelatin mix to the syrup and whisk them into a larger mixture. Take the mixture you made from the powdered gelatin and water and pour it into the syrup. Use a hand mixer to whisk the mix and the syrup together for 5-7 minutes until the mixture becomes 3 times larger in volume.[6]
  • Set your hand mixer to medium-high speed when you mix the gelatin and syrup together.
  • The new mixture should be cool and a snowy white color by the time you’re done whisking.
Whisk together the milk, powdered milk, and vanilla extract in a separate bowl. Pour 0.25 cups (59 mL) of cold milk, 12.75 grams (0.450 oz) of powdered milk, and 2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) of vanilla extract into a second bowl, then use a whisk or a hand mixer on low speed to beat the ingredients together. Whisk the ingredients until they’re completely mixed together into a smooth mixture.[7]
  • Make sure the powdered milk is completely dissolved into the mixture and that there are no clumps before proceeding to the next step.
Mix your vanilla milk mixture into the syrup. Pour 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of the vanilla milk mixture into your gelatin and syrup mix at a time and beat it with your hand mixer until the milk is completely incorporated into the syrup. Repeat this process until you’ve added all of your vanilla milk mixture to the syrup.[8]
  • Continue using your hand mixer at a medium-high speed throughout the process of adding the vanilla milk to the mixture.
  • Your new mixture should be completely smooth by the time you’ve finished incorporating the vanilla milk into it.
Cover the mixture with saran wrap and let it sit for 2-3 hours. Make sure the mixture is tightly covered with saran wrap so that air doesn’t get it into the container and cause the mix to go bad. Don’t put the mixture in the refrigerator at this point; it needs to sit out at room temperature for at least 2 hours to ensure your cool whip has a stable structure once it’s finished.[9]
  • Don’t leave the mixture out at room temperature for longer than 8 hours; this will cause the dairy products in the mix to spoil.
Drizzle heavy cream into the mixture while mixing it at a low speed. Pour 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of heavy cream into the mixture at a time and use your hand mixer to whisk the mixture at a low speed until the cream has been completely mixed into it. Repeat this process until all of the heavy cream has been added to the mixture.[10]
Beat the mixture at medium speed until it begins to form peaks. The peaks should be floppy but relatively firm. Once your whipped cream is able to hold medium-sized peaks that don’t disappear immediately when you stop mixing, it’s ready to be used.[11]
Use your whipped cream immediately or refrigerate or freeze it. For the freshest taste, use your homemade Cool Whip as soon as you’ve finished making it. However, if you don’t want to use the cream right away, transfer it into an airtight container and store it in the refrigerator or freezer to keep it from going bad.[12]
  • Whipped cream will stay fresh in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks or in the freezer for up to 3 months.
